description: Equivalent to reclaim (“return land to a suitable condition for use; claim back, repossess; return someone to a proper course of action, reform; cry out in opposition or contradiction”)  +‎ -atory. Compare exclamatory, declamatory.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to reclamation or reclaiming of land (that was underwater or unusable).
examples: This was a case of artificial reclamatory work done by the individual owners of the land beyond the foreshore, and the judgment of the Chief Justice (Osborne , C.J.) of the Nov. 5. Supreme Court of Southern Nigeria was affirmed,  […]

entries.meaning: Pertaining to reclamation or reclaiming of concepts, words, etc (that were stigmatized, disfavored, etc).
(religion, archaic) Reformative, corrective; (of a conversion) representing a return to orthodox religious faith and behavior.
examples: 2. Evangelism; efforts to secure reclamatory conversions. 3. Missionary activities; at home and abroad.

entries.meaning: (grammar, of a question) Asking for repetition (and sometimes expressing doubt or confusion).
